case_vignette: A 15-year-old white adolescent presents to the dermatology clinic with an asymptomatic rash on his upper back that has persisted for 4 months! Physical examination reveals hyperpigmented scaly papules coalescing into confluent plaques with peripheral reticulated papillomatosis! The boy is overweight but has no history of any other medical conditions!
question: What is the final diagnosis?

The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a rash on my upper back that has been there for four months.
Is the rash itchy or painful?
No, the rash is not itchy or painful.
Have there been any changes in texture or color of the skin in the affected area?
Yes, the affected area on my back has darker, scaly patches.
Have you tried any treatments or medications for these symptoms?
No, I have not tried any treatments or medications for these symptoms.
Do you have any personal or family history of skin conditions or autoimmune diseases?
No, I have no history of any other medical conditions or autoimmune diseases.
Final Diagnosis: Tinea Versicolor.

Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a rash on my upper back that has been there for about 4 months.
Has the rash changed in appearance or spread to other areas since it first appeared?
The rash has not spread to other areas, but it has developed into dark, scaly spots that are joining together into larger patches with a warty edge.
Do you have any associated symptoms such as itching, burning, or pain in the affected area?
No, the rash is asymptomatic; I don't feel any itching, burning, or pain.

No, I haven't tried any treatments or medications for the rash.
Final Diagnosis: Lichen Planus.
